awd_titl_txt: CC* Networking Infrastructure: Advancing High-speed Networking at UTC for Research and Education
awd_abstract_narration:
A diverse PI team including researchers and the Office of Information Technology at the University of Tennessee at Chattanooga (UTC) is upgrading the campus network infrastructure to improve the ability for professors and students to perform, enhance, and expand R&D activities. This project complements other significant and ongoing investments/upgrades at UTC to enhance campus intra- and inter-networking and research computing cyberinfrastructure. UTC's growing research portfolio of faculty-driven, data-oriented research drives the network upgrades. 100Gbit/s fiber networking infrastructure, switching, and routing infrastructure are upgraded by this project. A Science DMZ infrastructure and Data Transfer Node (DTN) server, both components used for inter-campus collaborations and tuned for large-scale data transfers, support the emerging uses of big data and data-centric external collaborations.

The project upgrades networking to eight UTC campus buildings representing all four university colleges (Engineering & Computer Science, Arts & Sciences, The Gary W. Rollins College of Business, and the College of Health, Education, and Professional Studies), as well as the Multidisciplinary Research Building (MDRB) and the campus library. In these buildings, at least fourteen science drivers (projects) on campus benefit from the proposed infrastructure; several of the projects are either NSF funded or otherwise externally supported. The co-location of three research centers plus UTC's research computing facilities in the MDRB adds to the campus impact.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
An 8-building, 100Gbit/s network was achieved at the University of Tennessee at Chattanooga campus, uniting the SimCenter (home of research computing and UTC's only TN Higher Education Commission-funded center) with researchers across campus.

In collaboration with UTC central IT, the PIs designed, deployed, and instrumented this network.  It is called the UTC research network.  It incorporates Data Transfer Nodes as well. By leveraging the VOIP to the desktop goal across campus, a minimum of 1Gbit/s connectivity to each professor's office in the 8 buildings was also achieved (at no cost to this effort).  UTC Central IT has taken responsibility for this network, providing for sustainability. 

This network has enabled PIs at UTC to pursue their R&D in Big data spokes for Biology, smart cities, and in general-purpose connectivity in a spoke-hub model to the SimCenter's research computing infrastructure, which also has been separately upgraded and supported by CC* Grants.

Because of Chattanooga's affordable 10-25Gbit/s network availability across a 700sq/mile region (based on a local provider), this network enables researchers and students at UTC to connect to the community to drive future big data, smart city, and other collaborative activities germane to the university's strong goal of community engagement.

Instrumentation with perfSonar shows high performance can be routinely achieved with the network as designed and deployed.

 

 


Last Modified: 09/23/2023
Modified by: Anthony Skjellum
